content:
Did you edit the stored password?

  • In Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'

If prompted for password: If you have previously set up to use 'Primary Password' then enter the Primary Password - do not be confused this is not a mail account password. If you have not set up 'Primary Password' then you ay see a 'Windows Security' window asking for password. When you start computer and enter user account password to see desktop - that is the password you need to enter.

Mail account will have two lines, one for incomin and one for outgoing smtp.

  • Right click on each line and select 'Edit Password'
  • Completely clear all content and then carefully type the correct password.
  • When finished, click on 'Close'

Now Exit Thunderbird , wait a few moments for background processes to complete and restart Thunderbird. It should then use the updated password.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content: Ik weet niet hoe het filter dat u gebruikt gedefinieerd is, maar als u een filter hebt dat op basis van trefwoorden berichten naar de Prullenbak of Ongewenst verplaatst, dan kunt u binnen dat filter extra regels opgeven met uitzonderingen voor bepaalde adressen. Dan worden berichten van die adressen niet verplaatst, in plaats van dat een ander filter ze weer terugzet.

content:
If you want to go back to a prior version then you would need to do this:

First I suggest you switch off the auto update and set it to ask you.

  • Settings > General
  • scroll down to 'Updates' section.
  • select 'Check for updates but let me choose whether to install them'


Exit Thunderbird Access Profile by:

  • in windows search type: %Appdata% - see attached image as guide
  • select '%Appdata% file folder
  • select 'Roaming' folder to see contents
  • Select 'Thunderbird' folder to see contents
  • Select 'Profiles' folder to see contents
  • Select profile name folder to see contents
  • Delete this file 'compatibility.ini' (this will allow you to go back to another version - a new gets recreated later)

Uninstall Thunderbird program

The ESR version eg: 128.9.1esr gets new functionality on an annual basis and security/bug fixes on a monthly basis. The 'Release' eg: 137.0.1 gets both new functionality and security/bug fixes on a monthly basis. The choice is up to you.

Get download from here: For Windows OS 64bit Thunderbird version 128.9.1esr:

  • https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/128.9.1esr/win64/

then select preferred language eg: en-GB is English British Click on the 'Thunderbird Setup 128.9.1esr.exe' to download so you can install it

For Windows OS 64bit Thunderbird version 137.0.1:

  • https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/137.0.1/win64/

then select preferred language eg: en-GB is English British Click on the 'Thunderbird Setup 137.0.1.exe' to download so you can install it
creator: Toad-Hall

I looked under all Appdata folders - no find a Thunderbird or mozzila folder.

What is the best way or ideal way to back up Thunderbird email account.
creator: dodson.rw

content:
Look in AppData\Local\Packages\MozillaThunderbird for your profile. copy to another folder for safekeeping Now, I suggest uninstalling thunderbird and then downloading from thunderbird.net and installing Then, start thunderbird and click tools>import>importfromathunderbirdinstallation, and then click 'choose a profile' and then select your copied profile. That will include your addressbook, and folders

Here are steps to backup and restore after the switch to thunderbird.net version:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
Thunderbird is free download from this official website:

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Thunderbird does rely on donations and they are very much appreciated, but none are required just to install and set up a mail account for any of your existing email addresses.

There is no such thing as 'opening a Thunderbird account' because Thunderbird is not a server and it does not provide email addresses.

However, you can create a mail account in Thunderbird for an existing email address so you can download, read and write emails.

It would help to understand your situation if you could provide some infomation as I'm not entirely sure what problem you are experiencing. What OS do you use ? What version of Thunderbird are you using?

Do the following anyway as they are required. Check your Firewall - it might be the default that came with computer or it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus product you installed. Thunderbird must be set up as an allowed program. Do not switch off Firewall as that is not adviseable.

Check computer for a VPN. If you have one enabled (some Anti-Virus products have a habit of switching them on) then switch it off because server do not like VPN as it hides your IP, so server thinks you might be someone else trying to hack the account.

How to create a mail account:

  • Menu app icon (3 line icon) > New Account > Email
  • Enter name
  • Enter full email address
  • Enter password (that's the same one you use to access webmail)
  • make sure to select checkbox so password manger remembers password.
  • Click on 'Continue'

Thunderbird by default will attempt to look up 'Imap' server settings, so if you want to use Pop you will need to adjust the setting - click on 'Manual Configuration' button.

Please note before you create the mail account - may need to set up additional settings depending upon the server. Some servers require you to select whether you want to allow Pop and or Imap which is done in the webmail account. Some servers such as At&T require you to use an App specific password also known as secure mail key in Thunderbird instead of the normal one used to access webmail account. Xfinity requires users to Check/select the box under Third Party Access Security to allow third-party programs access to your Xfinity Email - also done via webmail. Gmail uses oauth2 and this requires additional settings to allow cookies etc and this is set up in Thunderbird.

The point is this, I would need to know what server you are trying to connect to eg: yahoo, AT&T, comcast, BT, gmail etc then I may be able to advise on the server settings.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Gmail frequently stops allowing downloads if you use POP and have not been accessing the webmail account to delete a load of old messages that are stuck in the 'All Mail' folder. Anything you delete when you use Pop cannot put the gmail email into the gmail Trash server folder, so gmail just removes the 'Inbox' label and archives it in 'All Mail'.

This is a known thing that gmail will do to Pop users if they do not clear old mail which they think they have deleted. So I would suggest to do this now if you have not already done it.

There are very specific server settings and you cannot mix up a Pop account to use an imap server setting. Oauth2 is required for Pop and Imap and it requires a certain set up.

Please post the following information because I'm not entirely sure you set up the account correctly. In Thunderbird Help > Troubleshooting Information Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section Post an image which shows all the data in that section OR copy and paste all the data into this forum question.

Also - 115.18.0 ESR - is there a reason why you are using an old version of Thunderbird ? What OS are using?
creator: Toad-Hall
